tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires understanding the concept of static indeterminacy and how it changes with different support conditions. It involves multiple concepts from structural analysis and requires a few steps of reasoning to determine the change in the degree of indeterminacy. The image is important for visualizing the beam configurations.

answer_validation.reasoning: For a 2D beam, the available static equilibrium equations are three: \(\sum F_x = 0\), \(\sum F_y = 0\), and \(\sum M = 0\). A simply supported beam has a pin at one end (2 reaction components: horizontal and vertical) and a roller at the other (1 vertical reaction). Thus the total number of reaction unknowns is \(R_{ss} = 3\). Since \(R_{ss} = 3\), the degree of static indeterminacy is \(i_{ss} = R_{ss} - 3 = 0\); it is statically determinate. A fixed-fixed beam in 2D has each fixed support providing 3 reaction components (horizontal, vertical, and moment), so the total number of unknown reactions is \(R_{ff} = 3 + 3 = 6\). The degree of static indeterminacy is then \(i_{ff} = R_{ff} - 3 = 6 - 3 = 3\). Therefore, when converting from simply supported (indeterminacy 0) to fixed-fixed (indeterminacy 3), the degree of static indeterminacy increases by 3. Hence option A is correct.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recall that for a 2D beam we have three independent static equilibrium equations: \(\sum F_x = 0\), \(\sum F_y = 0\), and \(\sum M = 0\).

Step 2: Count the number of unknown reaction components for the simply supported beam: a pin support gives 2 reactions (horizontal and vertical) and a roller gives 1 vertical reaction, so total \(R_{ss} = 3\).
Step 3: Compute the degree of static indeterminacy for the simply supported beam as \(i_{ss} = R_{ss} - 3 = 3 - 3 = 0\); it is determinate.
Step 4: For the fixed-fixed beam, each fixed support provides 3 reactions (horizontal, vertical, and a moment), so total \(R_{ff} = 3 + 3 = 6\).
Step 5: Compute the degree of static indeterminacy for the fixed-fixed beam: \(i_{ff} = R_{ff} - 3 = 6 - 3 = 3\).
Step 6: Find the change in degree of indeterminacy when going from simply supported to fixed-fixed: \(\Delta i = i_{ff} - i_{ss} = 3 - 0 = 3\). Thus the degree of static indeterminacy increases by 3.

topic.name: Statically determinate and indeterminate beams
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures -> Strength of Materials and Structural Analysis -> Beams and frames

concepts.name: Support reactions for different supports (pin, roller, fixed)
Degree of static indeterminacy in 2D beams

essential: Equations of static equilibrium for planar structures
Types of beam supports and their reaction components (pin, roller, fixed)
Definition of statically determinate and indeterminate structures
Concept of degree of static indeterminacy in 2D beams
helpful: Basic structural analysis terminology (external vs internal indeterminacy)

Main Concept: requires: Equations of static equilibrium for planar structures
requires: Types of beam supports and their reaction components
enables: Ability to classify beams as determinate or indeterminate
enables: Advanced analysis of continuous and fixed-end beams using compatibility methods

difficulty_factors: Requires remembering reaction counts for each support type
Students may confuse total reactions with degree of indeterminacy

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: Types of beams and static determinacy
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a plane beam, three equations of equilibrium are available. If the number of external reaction components equals three, the structure is statically determinate; if greater, it is statically indeterminate to that excess.

textbook_references.author: J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige
textbook_references.section: Types of supports and their reactions
textbook_references.text_snippet: A fixed support in two dimensions exerts two force components and a couple moment on the member, whereas a pin exerts only two force components and a roller only one.

textbook_references.author: Beer and Johnston
textbook_references.text_snippet: Beams are classified as statically determinate or indeterminate depending on whether the support reactions can be found from the equations of equilibrium alone.

video_references.topic_covered: Classification of beams by support conditions and static determinacy
Statically determinate and indeterminate structures; degree of indeterminacy

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify support reactions for each configuration -> Compute degree of indeterminacy for each -> Take the difference
key_insights: Simply supported beam in 2D has exactly three reaction components, so it is determinate (indeterminacy zero).
Fixed-fixed beam in 2D has six reaction components, giving degree of indeterminacy three.
Degree of indeterminacy change is just the difference between these two values.

formulas_principles.name: Degree of static indeterminacy for 2D beam
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to planar beams considering only external reactions, where three independent equilibrium equations are available.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute the degree of indeterminacy from the number of unknown reaction components.

formulas_principles.name: Reaction count for simply supported 2D beam
formulas_principles.conditions: One pin support (2 reactions) and one roller support (1 reaction).
formulas_principles.relevance: Establishes that the simply supported beam is statically determinate.

formulas_principles.name: Reaction count for fixed-fixed 2D beam
formulas_principles.conditions: Each fixed support provides 3 reaction components: horizontal, vertical, and moment.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute the degree of indeterminacy of the fixed-fixed beam.

industry_examples: Design of aircraft wing spars where root is often fixed to the fuselage and additional constraints can make the structure statically indeterminate.
Bridge engineering where continuous or fixed-end beams are used to reduce mid-span deflections but require indeterminate analysis.
specific_systems: Fixed-fixed support of a landing gear support beam inside an aircraft fuselage frame.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Knowing how support conditions affect static indeterminacy is crucial for choosing appropriate analysis methods and understanding load redistribution and redundancy in aerospace structures.

common_mistakes.mistake: Confusing the number of reaction components with the degree of indeterminacy and answering that the degree increases by 6 instead of 3.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They forget to subtract the three available equilibrium equations and think indeterminacy equals total reactions.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write \(i = R - 3\) for 2D beams and compute both R and i explicitly.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to selecting an option that does not exist or misjudging how constrained the structure actually is.

common_mistakes.mistake: Miscounting reactions for the simply supported beam, assuming only vertical reactions (2) and ignoring the horizontal reaction at the pin.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus only on typical vertical loading and forget that the pin can resist horizontal forces.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize standard reaction sets: pin = 2, roller = 1, fixed = 3 in 2D, regardless of actual loading.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrectly concludes that the simply supported beam is already indeterminate or unstable.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that changing to fixed-fixed might decrease indeterminacy because the structure becomes 'stiffer' and 'more defined'.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They confuse stiffness with determinacy; a stiffer structure can still be more indeterminate.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Separate the ideas: determinacy is about solvability from statics; stiffness is about deformation under load.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing options C or D, which state a decrease in indeterminacy.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering reaction components for common supports in 2D.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever counting reactions for beams and frames.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Formula for degree of static indeterminacy in planar beams.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Apply when quickly checking if a beam is determinate or not.

flashcards.front: What is a statically determinate beam in 2D in terms of reactions and equilibrium equations?
flashcards.back: A beam for which the number of unknown external reaction components R equals the number of independent equilibrium equations (3 in 2D), so all reactions can be found from statics alone (i = R - 3 = 0).

flashcards.front: How many reaction components does a fixed support provide in a 2D beam?
flashcards.back: Three: one horizontal force, one vertical force, and one moment reaction.

flashcards.front: Write the formula for degree of static indeterminacy of a 2D beam in terms of number of reaction components R.
flashcards.back: For a planar beam, degree of static indeterminacy is i = R - 3.

flashcards.front: A simply supported 2D beam is converted to fixed-fixed. By how much does the degree of static indeterminacy change?
flashcards.back: Simply supported: R=3, i=0. Fixed-fixed: R=6, i=3. Change in indeterminacy = 3.

flashcards.front: Why is a simply supported 2D beam not statically indeterminate even though it has 3 reactions?
flashcards.back: Because there are also 3 independent equilibrium equations in 2D. Degree of indeterminacy is i = R - 3 = 3 - 3 = 0, so it is determinate.

real_world_context.application: Design of fixed-end beams in aircraft fuselage frames and wing roots.
real_world_context.industry_example: The wing-fuselage joint behaves closer to a fixed-fixed condition, making the load distribution indeterminate and requiring advanced structural analysis methods.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect assessment of determinacy can lead to using wrong analysis methods, underestimating stresses and deflections, and compromising structural safety.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Look at the supports, recall 2-1-3 rule for reactions, compute R and then i = R - 3. This is a quick 1-mark conceptual question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember that adding fixity (moments) usually increases indeterminacy, not decreases, so prefer options stating an increase.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to solve within about 1 minute; do not overthink, just count reactions and subtract 3.

search_keywords: degree of static indeterminacy of beams
simply supported vs fixed fixed beam reactions
types of beam supports pin roller fixed

alternative_methods.name: General determinacy check using unknowns vs equations
alternative_methods.description: Instead of memorizing i = R - 3, count all unknown external reactions and internal forces, then count all available equilibrium equations for the entire structure and its parts. Compare to see if the system is determinate or indeterminate.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: More general, works for complex frames and trusses. Cons: Overkill for simple beams; more time-consuming in an exam.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when dealing with frames or multi-member structures where internal indeterminacy may be present.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mechanics: Uses the same equilibrium equations and support reaction concepts introduced in rigid body statics.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: Indeterminate beams are often analyzed using FEM, where stiffness matrices naturally handle redundant reactions.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerospace Structures: Understanding determinacy is foundational for analyzing aircraft wings, fuselage frames, and landing gear supports.

deeper_dive_topics: Methods of consistent deformations for indeterminate beams
Effect of support settlements on indeterminate structures
Redundancy and structural safety in aerospace design

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Strength of Materials and Structural Analysis: Beams and frames, statically determinate and indeterminate structures
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Question aligns well with fundamental concepts of structural determinacy, appropriate for quick conceptual testing.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided multiple video-based explanations on statically determinate vs indeterminate beams, types of supports, and degree of indeterminacy. These directly supported the reasoning for counting reactions and computing the change in indeterminacy.

future_questions_potential: Given a continuous beam with three supports, compute its degree of static indeterminacy and compare with a simply supported beam of same span.
For a fixed-pinned beam in 2D, determine the degree of static indeterminacy and discuss how many compatibility equations are required.
Ask students to modify one support (e.g., replace roller with fixed) and predict the new degree of indeterminacy.
Include internal hinges and ask for combined external and internal degree of indeterminacy of a frame.
